image.altText: A composite image of eight different faces of men and women of different ages.

items.synopsis: As Australians prepare to vote in a historic referendum, the ABC's Voice correspondent Dan Bourchier travels to the north, west and east of the country for Four Corners and finds a nation grappling with its future.

title.children: The Voice asks a simple question, but Australia's answer is complicated

image.altText: newspaper clippings surrounding old photographs of a man

items.synopsis: Premier Daniel Andrews's new inquiry has been tasked with untangling a web of horrors relating to just 18 Victorian government schools. The single case of serial paedophile headmaster William Landman shows why a broader examination is needed, writes investigative reporter Russell Jackson.

title.children: Prolific paedophile William Landman was a criminal before he was a teacher. He and other abusers will not be examined in a new inquiry

image.altText: Crime figure Gavin Preston looks unsmilingly into the camera as he poses for a photo.

items.synopsis: Police continue to search for two men after a fatal shooting at a Keilor cafe, as CBD traders raise fears about Melbourne's reputation.

title.children: Search continues for two offenders after fatal cafe shooting of underworld figure Gavin Preston

image.altText: DeanYates

items.synopsis: WikiLeaks leaked a video showing two of former foreign correspondent Dean Yates's colleagues being killed. The truth left him reeling.

title.children: 'I felt responsible': Dean was guilt-ridden his staff died on his watch. Then WikiLeaks released the footage

image.altText: A young boy looking at the camera while kneeling near a pile of rubble.

items.synopsis: Everyone left in Moulay Ibrahim has a story of their narrow escape — just ask 11-year-old Abdarazak Abou Aalam, whose tragic tour of the town starts at his neighbour's house, which was destroyed in Friday's earthquake.

title.children: In this devastated Moroccan village, an 11yo earthquake survivor gives a tour of the rubble

image.altText: Novak Djokovic holds a silver trophy

items.synopsis: Novak Djokovic extends his dominance in men's tennis with a straight-sets victory over Daniil Medvedev to claim his 24th grand slam singles title and his fourth at the US Open.

title.children: Awe-inspiring Novak Djokovic wins record-equalling US Open title

image.altText: A man in blue facing a crowd arms raised with a tennis racket in one hand.

items.synopsis: Your place for today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Djokovic now two ahead of Nadal in men's grand slam tournament count following US Open win. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Novak Djokovic has come out victorious over Daniil Medvedev, winning in straight sets at the US Open to claim the men's title. It's Djokovic's fourth US Open title, winning 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3. He'll consider the win a redemption against the Russian who he lost against two years ago, denying Djokovic his first calendar-year Grand Slam. Djokovic has 24 grand slams tournaments, placing two ahead of Rafael Nadal in the all time major wins count for men
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Djokovic's vengeance after claiming US Open title against Medvedev

featuredLink.title: Novak Djokovic wins US Open title

props.alt: Novak Djokovic with his arms raised

children.content: Novak Djokovic has come out victorious over Daniil Medvedev, winning in straight sets at the US Open to claim the men's title.
It's Djokovic's fourth US Open title, winning 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3.
He'll consider the win a redemption against the Russian who he lost against two years ago, denying Djokovic his first calendar-year Grand Slam.
Djokovic has 24 grand slams tournaments, placing two ahead of Rafael Nadal in the all time major wins count for men

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After a massive rally against Daniil Medvedev, Novak Djokovic has collapsed to the ground out of exhaustion. Djokovic is two sets up against Medvedev, having won the second in a tie-break just moments ago. He leads 6-3, 7-6 (7/5). We are waiting on a medical time-out as Medvedev's trainers give his shoulder some treatment, but play should be back underway very soon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Djokovic collapses on court after marathon rally

props.alt: Djokovic lying on the ground of a tennis green

children.content: After a massive rally against Daniil Medvedev, Novak Djokovic has collapsed to the ground out of exhaustion.
Djokovic is two sets up against Medvedev, having won the second in a tie-break just moments ago.
We are waiting on a medical time-out as Medvedev's trainers give his shoulder some treatment, but play should be back underway very soon.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Air quality in Sydney's east this morning remains very poor as key hazard reduction burns continue today. Sarah Hawke in Sydney reports: "Smoke has settled across many parts of Sydney from the burns at Holsworthy in the south west and and in the Ku-ring-gai Chase National Park in in the north. "The Rural Fire Service says these areas haven't been burnt for a number of years and if fuel loads aren't reduced hundreds if not thousands of homes would be at risk during the fire season." The air quality in Sydney's east is rated as very poor and it's poor across the north west.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Very poor air quality in parts of Sydney following reduction burns

featuredLink.title: Air quality 'very poor' in Sydney's east as firefighters 'catch-up' on hazard reduction burning

children.content: Air quality in Sydney's east this morning remains very poor as key hazard reduction burns continue today.
"Smoke has settled across many parts of Sydney from the burns at Holsworthy in the south west and and in the Ku-ring-gai Chase National Park in in the north.
"The Rural Fire Service says these areas haven't been burnt for a number of years and if fuel loads aren't reduced hundreds if not thousands of homes would be at risk during the fire season."
The air quality in Sydney's east is rated as very poor and it's poor across the north west.

items.synopsis: Police now say a man with stab wounds who was let out of a stolen car in Preston had not been abducted. Four people have been arrested.

title.children: Four people arrested over stolen car, earlier report of abduction now dismissed

image.altText: A close up of marigold flowers in an urban environment.

items.synopsis: Green roofs are proven to boost biodiversity, energy efficiency and people's wellbeing. But, unlike other countries, Australia's big cities have just a few dozen.

title.children: Green roofs bring many benefits, but gardening up high poses some unique challenges

image.altText: An illustration of a car, house, health kit and book in an opened gift box

items.synopsis: Some experts say a salary sacrifice or a salary package agreement can help maximise income and reduce tax debt — depending on the industry you're in and what your employer offers.

title.children: Ever heard of salary sacrifice? Here's what it is and how it can help reduce debt

image.altText: Oxfam office

items.synopsis: With unions embedding trials of the four-day work week in industrial agreements, is this the moment the working-hour-reducing concept goes mainstream?

title.children: Four-day week enshrined in first Australian union agreement, with concept spreading

image.altText: planes on an airport runway

items.synopsis: Qantas' board remains under pressure ahead of its annual report, including over whether former CEO Alan Joyce should receive his full bonus, and what the board knew about the ACCC's ghost flights investigation. Meanwhile, the ASX has opened lower. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas board under pressure over Joyce bonus and ghost flights, tech stocks higher ahead of iPhone 15 release, ASX down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian sharemarket has opened lower on Monday, down 0.2% to 7,414 points as of 10:25am AEST. (For live figures at any time, jump to the post at the top of the blog.) A disappointing financial forecast from scrap recycler Sims has dragged the market lower, after it forecast it would break even during the first quarter of the 2024 financial year because of ongoing demand issues and the scrap price. Tech stocks have also pulled the market lower, with Block down around 4% in the early session, in response to Friday's outage. As for the sectors, industrials is down 1.5%, real estate down 0.8%, and healthcare and technology down 0.5% each. Energy and academic and educational services are up 0.4% each, and financials has gained 0.3%. The top five movers so far: Syrah Resources +11.4% PEXA Group +3% Imugene +2.5% Magellan Financial Group +2.4% Evolution Mining +1.8% The bottom five performers so far: Sims -11.8% Lake Resources -5.3% Megaport -4.8% Chorus -4.3% Block -4.1%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX dragged lower by tech stocks, Sims disappointing financial forecast

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Oil prices are still picking up speed, with Brent crude up around 2.4% last week, staying above $US90 a barrel. The reason for the gain is still in response to Russia and Saudi Arabia announcing it would be extending its production and export cuts last Tuesday. The countries extended the voluntary cuts by a combined 1.3 million barrels per day, through to the end of the year. Brent has risen by around 20% since July 1, and the pricing above $US90 a barrel is the highest the benchmark has been since mid-November. The high oil price comes as petrol prices remain around $2 a litre, if not higher, around Australia.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Oil prices remain above $US90 a barrel in response to production and export cuts

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A new study of the top 300 publicly listed companies on the ASX has found that women are more likely than men to be sitting on the boards of multiple companies, but they are less likely to be earning as much as their male counterparts and to be in the chair position. Data analysed by Ownership Matters and provided to the ABC found one in three non-executive directors in Australia's biggest 300 companies are women, but they are substantially underrepresented as chairs and chief executives. It's the second time Ownership Matters has analysed the public company boards. It found only 33 companies have boards chaired by women, while only four companies have both female chairs and CEOs. There are also 15 company directors who received more than $1 million in the 2022 financial year, with Maxine Brenner the only woman in the mix. She's on the boards o f Qantas, Woolworths, Origin Energy and Orica, but has since left Orica and joined Telstra as a director. She is also the second-highest paid Qantas board member, behind chairman Richard Goyder — who is the second-highest-paid non-executive director in the country. You can read the full story from me below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Women more likely to be sitting on multiple boards, but still earning less than men

featuredLink.title: Nice work if you can get it: Australian boardrooms dominated by men earning over $1m despite more female directors

image.altText: Joe Biden stands behind a lectern with a Vietnamese flag in the background.
